comment.author: 43671133302@N01
comment._content: Note that the handwritten caption on the photo says "Crown Prince Sweden," not "Seden."

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: The Crown Prince in the photo must be Gustav VI Adolf, who was King of Sweden from 1950 to 1973. He was born in 1882, and had close ties to England, having been married in 1905 to Princess Margaret of Connaught, a Granddaughter of Queen Victoria.

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: Here is a photo of Gustav VI Adolf and family taken in 1912. Looks like a plausible match. Surely that is some other Swedish dignitary on the right--he seems very formally dressed. An Uncle, perhaps? Seems like this visit (if it is in the US) should show up in the New York Times. I did a quick search, but did not see it.

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: The caption mentions English football players, so I'd surmise this photo was taken in England. A number of other photos in the Bain collection were taken in England.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for catching the misspelling and providing additional information. We'll update the source data and reload the description in Flickr.

comment.author: 83197034@N00
comment._content:
You're right, whyaduck, but a number of photos were taken in Sweden too (including a few adjacent to this one in the LoC photostream)

Prior to 1947, though, England played Sweden only once in England, in Hull in November 1909, and a) the Crown Prince doesn't look dressed for a howling North Sea November gale, and b) I can't really see him making the journey to Hull in any case.

It's more likely to be either Göteborg on 1908-09-08  (Sweden lost 1 - 6) or Stockholm on 1914-06-10 (Sweden lost  1 - 5).

They did also play in London in the 1908 Olympic Games (lost 1-12) though, where the Great Britain side was actually the English amateur team (because Scotland, Ireland and Wales refuse to allow players to represent Great Britain at football).

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: JosefM: Thanks for the additional information. You clearly know much more about football than I do.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The 1912 Olympics were in Sweden and there are other photos from Sweden in the Bain collection on Flickr (e.g., www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2536795168/ ). Great Britain won the gold for football (soccer). According to www.sok.se/inenglish/stockholm1912.4.18ea16851076df636228... "Before an audience of 25,000, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf declared the Olympics opened on the 6th of July at the Olympic Stadium. A total number of 327,288 would get to see the Games, which took place under a clear blue Stockholm sky. By the way, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf had been very active in the preparations for the Games and his involvement was very significant." So this may be from 1912. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Football_at_the_1912_Summer_O... for a photo of the 1912 team. It seems to be in the same stadium -- look at the decorations above the stands. And I see the same goalie in both pictures. Some other players could be the same too.

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: swang: You're probably right about the time and place of this photo. It looks to me as though there are indeed several of the same players in both pictures, and it's surely the same stadium with the same decorations.
